Hey,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@m...> wrote:
> Ben Mau=
rer wrote:
> > Ant XML output
> > --------------
> > [...]
> > However, in =
rc2, it looks like:
> >
> > <testcase classname=3D"junit.framework.JUnit4Te=
stAdapterCache$2$1" 
> > name=3D"unknown" time=3D"0.018"></testcase>
> That=
 doesn't look good, does it?  If my initial guess as to this bug's 
> sourc=
e is correct, this will be easily fixed (back to rc1's
behavior, at 
> leas=
t) soon.

Ok, that's good. That will at least allow me to upgrade ;-). It'd=
 be
ideal if we could set the classname to the "real" class name.

Btw, on =
the topic of JUnit3 tool compat: is it possible to make is so
we don't have=
 to write:

        public static junit.framework.Test suite()
        {
  =
              return new
junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter(HashtableTest.cl=
ass);
        }

*if* we are using the JUnit4 version of the tools. The log=
ic could be
something like:

if (I am asked to run a junit3 test on somethi=
ng) {
   if (any methods have the @Test annotation) {
      use junit4 beha=
vior
   }

   fallback
}

If this was done and the classname was set correc=
tly, I think we could
simulate almost full compat (for simple cases) with j=
unit3 based tools.

If you get both/either of these in cvs, I'd be happy to=
 test them out.

> > Stack Trace Filtering
> > ---------------------
> >
> =
> The stack trace from junit messages have always been filed with
junit.*
>=
 > traces. Ant filters these out. However, now there are org.junit things
>=
 > slipping through. Also, tests with a timeout, have many
> > java.util.co=
ncurrent frames in them. Why leave this kind of
filtering up
> > to each to=
ol? JUnit should filter out the frames it knows are from it.
> > This would=
 make command line output look nicer. I think NUnit does
this.
> This is tr=
icky.  The JUnit API actually reports the Exception
objects to 
> the tools=
, which are then responsible for displaying / parsing stack 
> traces.  I d=
on't know that there's anything we could do to make 
> pre-JUnit 4 tools au=
tomatically filter the org.junit lines, but we
might 
> look at something f=
or the future.

There's a setStackTrace in Throwable that looks promising. =
Granted,
this is a bit of a hack, but having the org.junit lines in the tes=
t
results gets really, really annoying. At the very least we should
export =
a polished method that takes care of this.

> > @Test(expected=3D) traces
>=
 > -----------------------
> >
> > When you have an expected exception, and=
 another one gets thrown, the
> > error trace doesn't contain the bad excep=
tion. You only get:
> >
> > java.lang.AssertionError: Unexpected exception,=
 
> > expected<java.util.NoSuchElementException> but 
> > was<java.lang.Nul=
lPointerException>
> >
> > Having the trace of the bad exception would help=
 TAs debug student
code. 
> That's a good idea.  We'll try to have that in =
the next release.

Thanks. This also comes up with timeouts. It'd be really=
 cool to have
a stacktrace from where the thread was hung.

Oh, and since I=
'm talking to another person from a school with a great
CS dept ;-), I'm re=
ally interested in writing good docs for students
on how to write test suit=
es, especially for data structures (the focus
of the 15-211 course). I have=
 something that I hacked up for our first
homework, however, this kind of t=
hing would be great to make into a
tutorial that could be used by other cla=
sses.

-- Ben
